G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Rachel Thompson, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and the equitable power of this Court, and respectfully requests that this Honorable Court modify the existing custody order entered on May 15, 2018, in the Norfolk Probate and Family Court, concerning the custody of Emily Thompson, the parties' minor child.

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: In Massachusetts, modifying a custody order requires a material and substantial change in circumstances and a determination that the modification is in the best interests of the child.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly refuses to apply the "substantial change in circumstances" standard and instead treats the matter as an initial custody determination governed by the best interests of the child under G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a). The court notes that the "substantial change" standard applies to modification proceedings under § 20, but holds that this case was not such a modification action. Thus, the case does not stand for the general proposition that modifying a custody order in Massachusetts always requires both a material change in circumstances and a best-interests finding.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.proposition: Daniel Thompson’s diagnosis of a progressive neurological condition, his resulting physical limitations, and the impact on the safety and well-being of Emily constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion in Hunter v. Rose deals with recognition of a California registered domestic partnership, determination of legal parentage, custody based on best interests, and attorney’s fees. It does not mention Daniel Thompson, a progressive neurological condition, or analyze whether a parent’s medical deterioration and resulting limitations constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances. Because the case does not address modification standards or material change in circumstances grounded in a parent’s health condition, it does not support the stated proposition.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children… ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is]… what is ‘best for the child’….’ … The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: The Court is guided in custody matters by the "best interests of the child" standard.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in removal and custody determinations, the “best interests of the child” standard is the governing test. The court interprets the statutory phrase “upon cause shown” in the removal statute to mean that removal must be in the best interests of the child and then explains how those best interests are to be evaluated, confirming that this is the guiding standard in such custody-related matters.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … [a child] shall not … be removed out of this commonwealth … unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755, 766.proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court has emphasized that stability, safety, and the developmental needs of the child are paramount in determining custody issues.
*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755, 766.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses parental fitness, the State’s parens patriae role, and the need to protect children from endangerment, and it briefly notes the child’s need for family stability. However, it does not articulate a broad, stand‑alone principle that stability, safety, and developmental needs are "paramount" in custody determinations. The focus is instead on the statutory policy favoring family preservation and the requirement of proven parental unfitness, not a best‑interests formulation centered expressly on stability and developmental needs.
*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755, 766.relevant_excerpt: The Legislature has declared that the policy of this Commonwealth is “to direct its efforts, first, to the strengthening and encouragement of family life for the protection and care of children; to assist and encourage the use by any family of all available resources to this end; and to provide substitute care of children only when the family itself or the resources available to the family are unable to provide the necessary care and protection to insure the rights of any child to sound health and normal physical, mental, spiritual and moral development.” G. L. c. 119, § 1.

*Bezio v. Patenaude*, 381 Mass. 563, 576.proposition: The current custodial arrangement exposes Emily to unnecessary safety risks and responsibilities beyond her ability, which are not in her best interests.
*Bezio v. Patenaude*, 381 Mass. 563, 576.support_reasoning: The opinion is about standards for revoking a guardianship and the necessity of a finding of parental unfitness, not about a custodial arrangement exposing a child to concrete safety risks or age-inappropriate responsibilities. While the court criticizes reliance on the mother’s lesbian household as a basis to deny custody, it does not find that the existing custodial arrangement with the guardian exposes the children to safety dangers or burdens beyond their abilities. Thus, it does not provide authority for the proposition that the current custodial arrangement creates unnecessary safety risks or excessive responsibilities for Emily or that such risks are contrary to her best interests.
*Bezio v. Patenaude*, 381 Mass. 563, 576.relevant_excerpt: “In deciding that the guardian should retain custody, the judge noted that Magdalena ‘has provided an excellent home and care for these children. She loves the children and they love her. The children love their natural mother and desire to visit with her but they regard the defendant as their real mother. ... It would cause great trauma with the children to remove them from a home where they are happy and secure and from the custody of one who loves them and has their welfare at heart. Their best interest requires that they remain with the defendant.’”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.proposition: Modifying the custody order to grant Rachel Thompson primary physical custody will better ensure Emily’s emotional and physical needs are met.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns whether modifying a custody order to give a particular parent (Rachel Thompson) primary physical custody will better meet a child’s emotional and physical needs. Rolde v. Rolde addresses Massachusetts custody standards in general—best interests of the child, preference for stability, the significance of the primary nurturing parent, and the inappropriateness of joint custody in high-conflict situations—but it does not involve or discuss any modification of custody, nor does it address the specific factual conclusion that a change in primary custody will better meet a child’s needs. The case is useful for general best‑interests principles (e.g., importance of the primary caretaker and minimizing disruption), but it does not itself stand as authority for the specific proposition about modifying custody to grant Rachel Thompson primary physical custody.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children. Although the husband had had involvement with the child rearing functions and responsibilities, the judge concluded that… an order providing joint custody would run contrary to the children’s happiness and welfare.”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Defendant’s medical condition and its implications also suggest that shared physical custody may no longer be feasible or appropriate.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss any party’s medical condition or analyze how a medical condition affects the feasibility or appropriateness of shared physical custody. Its custody analysis focuses on relocation, work schedules, extended family, and the lack of a material and substantial change in circumstances, ultimately rejecting the modification to shared physical custody. Thus it provides no authority for the specific proposition that a defendant’s medical condition suggests shared physical custody may no longer be feasible or appropriate.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’… There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements….”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (.proposition: The stability provided by a primary residence with the Plaintiff is in Emily’s best interests.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (.support_reasoning: The case addresses the children’s best interests in the context of a relocation/removal dispute, but it does not discuss or endorse the idea that a “primary residence with the Plaintiff” (here, the father) provides stability that is in any specific child’s best interests. Instead, the court affirms an order continuing shared legal and physical custody and denying removal because relocation would be detrimental, focusing on school quality, special needs, and maintaining relationships with both parents. It therefore does not stand for a proposition favoring a primary residence with one parent as being in the child’s best interests.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (.relevant_excerpt: “After some time, and a four-day trial, a different judge weighed the best interests of the children and determined that removal to New Hampshire in the manner requested by the mother was not in the best interests of the children and thus would not be authorized by the court. … The judge did not award sole physical custody to either party, deciding instead to order continued shared legal and physical custody.”

*Fort v. Fort*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 411, 4.proposition: The Plaintiff proposes a parenting plan that maximizes safe and meaningful time between Emily and the Defendant while prioritizing her well-being.
*Fort v. Fort*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 411, 4.support_reasoning: The case concerns how a court should evaluate parental conduct (specifically cohabitation and marital misconduct) in deciding custody based on the child’s best interests. It does not involve or endorse a parent’s proposed parenting plan, nor does it discuss maximizing safe and meaningful time with the noncustodial parent; instead, it upholds awarding custody to the father based on comparative household stability and emotional environment. Thus, it does not provide authority for the proposition about the plaintiff’s proposed parenting plan structure or its goals.
*Fort v. Fort*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 411, 4.relevant_excerpt: “The determination of custody is a choice among limited alternatives, all of which, invariably, have imperfections, often serious imperfections. The judgment that is called for is a realistic, commonsense judgment, one which weighs the practical significance of those imperfections or deficiencies in terms of their effect on the well-being of the child and his future development… The determinative focus was on a specific comparison between the husband’s steady disposition and even temperament and the relative tranquility of his living arrangement… This was a proper basis for awarding custody of the youngest child to the husband.”
